channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Biden and Putin Talk Amid Fears of Ukraine Invasion Plan
item.description: With signs of a substantial Russian military buildup, Western leaders hope the summit can avert a crisis. But in the trenches along the Ukrainian front line, as machine-gun fire echoes in the distance, there is little hope that diplomacy will end the grinding conflict.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: Can Olaf Scholz, Germany’s New Chancellor, Revive the Left in Europe?
item.description: Olaf Scholz wants to win back workers who defected to the populist far right. Success could make him a model for Social Democrats everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, center right, with members of the Social Democratic party’s parliamentary group in in Berlin in September. Mr. Scholz will be Germany’s ninth postwar chancellor.

item.title: Ahead of Biden’s Democracy Summit, China Says: We’re Also a Democracy
item.description: Beijing argues that its system represents a distinctive form of democracy, one that has dealt better than the West with challenges like the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, at their virtual summit last month, as seen on a Chinese news program on a giant outdoor screen in Beijing.

item.title: How Many Countries Will Follow the U.S. Boycott of Beijing’s Olympics?
item.description: Several have signaled that they will find ways to protest China’s human rights abuses, whether they declare a diplomatic boycott or not.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Steven Erlanger
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Winter Olympics countdown display in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: For Ukraine's Soldiers, Anticipation of Invasion by Putin's Russia
item.description: After eight years in the trenches, Ukrainian soldiers are resigned to the possibility that the Russian military, which dwarfs their own in power and wealth, will come sooner or later.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Expected to Offer Warnings and Alternatives in Call With Putin
item.description: The conflict in Ukraine will be a major topic during a high-stakes video call between President Biden and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some of President Biden’s aides are doubtful that diplomacy can dissuade Vladimir V. Putin from his fundamental goal of destabilizing Ukraine’s government.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Plunge Into Organic Farming Brings Disaster
item.description: The economically troubled country banned chemical fertilizers without preparing farmers, prompting a surge in food prices and worries about shortages.
item.dc:creator: Aanya Wipulasena and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: A vegetable seller at a market in Colombo, Sri Lanka, last month.

item.title: Photos From Indonesia Volcano: Death Toll Rises
item.description: About 17 people were still missing as rescuers searched for survivors buried under volcanic ash.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: With Mount Semeru still spewing ash and smoke in the background on Tuesday, a motorcyclist and his passengers headed elsewhere in Gunung Sawur, Candipuro, Indonesia.

item.title: Early Omicron Reports Say Illness May Be Less Severe
item.description: Researchers in South Africa, where the variant is spreading quickly, say it may cause less serious Covid cases than other forms of the virus, but it is unclear whether that will hold true.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, Richard Pérez-Peña and Emily Anthes
item.media:description: A vaccination site in Johannesburg, South Africa.

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Falls, but Myanmar’s Democratic Hopes Move On
item.description: The ousted civilian leader faces years in custody after being sentenced on the first of several charges. In her absence, a new generation of younger, more progressive politicians is emerging.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2019.

item.title: India and Russia Expand Defense Ties, Despite Prospect of U.S. Sanctions
item.description: India’s purchase of a missile defense system signaled that it was more worried about an emboldened China at its borders than about angering the United States.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin came to visit Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday in New Delhi, where the two leaders announced a missile defense system deal was going forward.

item.title: Karl Nehammer Becomes Scandal-Shaken Austria's 3rd Chancellor This Year
item.description: Karl Nehammer, the former interior minister, becomes the country’s leader two months after the resignation of Sebastian Kurz, amid an investigation into corruption and influence-peddling.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Georg Hochmuth/APA , via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: Karl Nehammer, left, Austria’s newly appointed chancellor, in Vienna on Monday with his predecessor, Alexander Schallenberg.

item.title: Why Is Russia Massing Troops on Its Ukraine Border?
item.description: There are tactical reasons for threatening an invasion, but the real cause may lie in the Kremlin’s fixation with righting what it sees as a historical injustice.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia watching a military exercise in September.

item.title: Chinese Tourists Aren't Coming Back Any Time Soon
item.description: Even before Omicron’s arrival, China was discouraging its citizens from traveling abroad. That has had a huge impact on global tourism.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Elisabetta Povoledo, Muktita Suhartono and Léontine Gallois
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Kasia Strek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese visiting Prague’s city center in October 2019.

item.title: Chile Legalizes Same-Sex Marriage at Fraught Political Moment
item.description: The battle to legalize same-sex marriage in Chile began more than a decade ago and it comes to an end as the candidates vying to run Chile are at odds on the issue.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: A demonstration in Santiago, Chile, in support of same-sex marriage.

item.title: This Robot Looks Like a Pancake and Jumps Like a Maggot
item.description: Researchers designed a soft, legless robot that can hop and navigate obstacle courses.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler

item.title: Ethiopia Says It Recaptured 2 Strategic Towns From Tigray Rebels
item.description: The government said it took back the towns of Dessie and Kombolcha, the latest in a string of wins Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has claimed in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Members of the Ethiopian National Defense Force transporting an antiaircraft gun in Shewa Robit on Sunday.

item.title: Do Tests Work on the Omicron Variant and Other Questions, Answered
item.description: And experts’ answers.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A vaccination site in Johannesburg.

item.title: Novak Djokovic to Play in ATP Cup, Organizers Say
item.description: The announcement came after weeks of speculation about whether Djokovic would travel to Australia. It’s still uncertain if he’ll play in the Australian Open.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic of Serbia at the ATP Cup in Melbourne, Australia, in February 2021.

item.title: On the Banks of the Furious Congo River, a 5-Star Emporium of Ambition
item.description: As the clean energy revolution upends the centuries-long lock of fossil fuels on the global economy, dealmakers and hustlers converge on the Fleuve Congo Hotel.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton, Michael Forsythe and Ashley Gilbertson

item.title: It’s Never Too Late to Go to College and Rewrite Your Story
item.description: Devon Simmons served 15 years in prison for crimes he committed as a teenager. Since then, he’s been on a mission to remake not just his own life, but the legal system itself.
item.dc:creator: Chris Colin
item.category: John Jay College of Criminal Justice
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Devon Simmons at Columbia University, where he cocreated a program to help the formerly incarcerated.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Early reports on Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A vaccination site last week in Johannesburg, South Africa.

item.title: Michael Steinhardt, Billionaire, Surrenders $70 Million in Stolen Relics
item.description: The hedge fund pioneer is barred for life from buying more antiquities. He turned over 180 stolen objects that had decorated his homes and office.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:description: Michael H. Steinhardt in 2006. The district attorney’s office on Monday announced an agreement barring Mr. Steinhardt, a hedge fund billionaire, from ever acquiring antiquities again. He surrendered 180 stolen, trafficked pieces.

item.title: ‘Selling Kabul’ Review: Trapped in a War, and an Apartment
item.description: In Sylvia Khoury’s suspenseful new play, the characters sometimes feel too much like wheels in a machine, but it’s a tense thrill to watch it work.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:description: Dario Ladani Sanchez as Taroon and Marjan Neshat as Afiya in the Sylvia Khoury play “Selling Kabul” at Playwrights Horizons.

item.title: Thinking of hosting a holiday party? Here are a few tips.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Aung San Suu Kyi is convicted in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2019.

item.title: N.Y.C. religious schools face a vaccine mandate. Will they fight it?
item.dc:creator: Emma Fitzsimmons, Liam Stack and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:description: People attend a vigil for teachers challenging a New York City coronavirus vaccine mandate at Foley Square in November in New York City.

item.title: U.S. Will Not Send Government Officials to Beijing Olympics
item.description: American athletes will still be able to compete in the Winter Games, but the diplomatic boycott is a slap at China for human rights abuses in Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Near the headquarters of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics organizing committee, at the Shougang Industrial Park in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Travelers to U.S. Now Must Test Negative for Covid a Day Before Flying
item.description: Inbound travelers must now show a negative result from a test taken no more than a day before departure, a requirement some say may be hard to satisfy.
item.dc:creator: Juston Jones and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at Kennedy International Airport on the Sunday before Thanksgiving.

item.title: Pope Exploring a 2nd Meeting With Russian Orthodox Church
item.description: Speaking after his trip to Cyprus and Greece, Francis also said he had no choice but to accept the resignation of the archbishop of Paris because of the harmful gossip surrounding him.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Pope Francis departing Athens on Monday after a five-day visit to Cyprus and Greece in which he tried to put the global spotlight on the plight of migrants.

item.title: 8 Women and 8 Men: Germany Gets Its First Gender-Equal Cabinet
item.description: Angela Merkel is handing over the chancellery to a man. But in a watershed moment for the country, women will run all security and diplomacy-related ministries in the new government.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, the incoming chancellor, left, with members of his new cabinet in Berlin on Monday.

item.title: Three of a Group of Missionaries Kidnapped in Haiti Have Been Released
item.description: A U.S. Christian aid group said three more people were released of the 17 who had been kidnapped by a gang in Haiti. Two were released last month.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Outside the Christian Aid Ministries headquarters last month in Titanyen, north of Port-au-Prince.

item.title: Russia finds its first two cases of the Omicron variant in travelers from South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A medical worker prepares a shot of a Russian coronavirus vaccine at a vaccination center in Moscow in October.

item.title: China Calls on ‘Little Inoculated Warriors’ to Defeat Covid.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
item.media:description: Children receiving coronavirus vaccinations in Wuhan, China, in November.

item.title: A Terrible Catch-22
item.description: Should wrongfully convicted people falsely admit guilt to win parole?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Garr Keith Hardin, left, and Jeffrey Clark in 2018.

item.title: Thailand Reports First Case of Omicron Variant
item.description: A U.S. citizen who entered the country nearly a week ago received his first positive test result on Dec. 1. Thailand has pushed to reopen to tourists, aiming to revive its economy.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Wearing face masks at a train station in Bangkok last week.

item.title: New variant means China’s big spenders won’t be traveling any time soon.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Elisabetta Povoledo, Muktita Suhartono and Léontine Gallois
item.media:credit: Kasia Strek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese tourists in Prague’s city center in October 2019.

item.title: Companies Linked to Russian Ransomware Hide in Plain Sight
item.description: Cybersecurity experts tracing money paid by American businesses to Russian ransomware gangs found it led to one of Moscow’s most prestigious addresses.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cybersecurity experts say millions of dollars paid by American companies in ransomware have passed through Federation Tower East, the tallest building in Russia’s capital.

item.title: Bearing Witness to Svalbard’s Fragile Splendor
item.description: To visitors, the Norwegian archipelago can seem both ethereal and eternal. But climate change all but guarantees an eventual collapse of its vulnerable ecosystem.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Westberg

item.title: The Pandemic Has Your Blood Pressure Rising? You’re Not Alone.
item.description: Average blood pressure readings increased as the coronavirus spread, new research suggests. The finding portends medical repercussions far beyond Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Health workers checking blood pressure readings before administering coronavirus vaccines in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, in July.

item.title: China Calls on ‘Little Inoculated Warriors’ in Its War on Covid-19
item.description: The country regards children as crucial in its quest for herd immunity, but some parents, worried about the vaccines’ safety, are pushing back.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
item.media:description: China approved the use of its Sinovac and Sinopharm vaccines for children between the ages of 3 and 17 in June, but started widely using it in those under 12 only in late October.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Omicron in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: People walk past a Selfridge’s store on Oxford Street in London on Sunday. Britain reported 86 new confirmed coronavirus cases of the new Omicron.

item.title: Norodom Ranariddh, Royal Player in Cambodian Politics, Dies at 77
item.description: He rode a wave of royalist sentiment to win a United Nations-sponsored election in 1993, but was later ousted in a power struggle with his co-prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who briefly served as co-prime minister of Cambodia, leaving a palace ceremony to enter the monkhood, a royal family tradition, in 1996.

item.title: Europe is on edge as Omicron cases rise quickly before the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Shoppers on Oxford Street in London on Sunday. Britain has reported 246 cases and counting of the Omicron coronavirus variant.

item.title: N.Y.C. companies that don’t rely on the global supply chain are faring quite well.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:description: Science technology company Nanotronics, which uses local manufacturing, is doing well while many other companies have struggled from supply chain woes.

item.title: Spike in Omicron Variant Cases Puts Europe on Edge
item.description: With cases of the Omicron variant rising in Europe, there are worries that even tougher restrictions are looming over a holiday period that many had hoped would be a return to some normalcy.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Shoppers on Oxford Street in London on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Omicron’s rapid spread.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: An international traveler received a coronavirus test in Johannesburg last week.

item.title: Pope Francis Laments That for Migrants, ‘Little Has Changed’
item.description: At a Greek refugee camp, Francis lamented the hardening of hearts against asylum seekers, whose plight he called a “shipwreck of civilization.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Pope Francis visited the Mavrovouni refugee camp on the Greek island of Lesbos on Sunday.

item.title: Britain and Denmark Report Rise in Known Omicron Cases
item.description: The nations are widely perceived as leaders in genomic sequencing and testing, giving them an edge over tracking the spread of the virus and its mutations.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Thomas Erdbrink
item.media:description: Confirmed Omicron cases in Britain have nearly doubled since Friday. The government is urging vaccines and boosters, but has no plans to limit gatherings during the holiday season.

item.title: Anger Spreads in Northeastern India After Security Forces Kill 14 Civilians
item.description: Eight mine workers were shot in a mistaken ambush by soldiers seeking insurgents, and six protesters died later in clashes with government forces, stoking fears of further violence in the restive region.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: An Indian Army convoy in Kohima, capital of the northeastern Indian state of Nagaland, on Sunday.

item.title: On Syria’s Ruins, a Drug Empire Flourishes
item.description: Powerful associates of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, are making and selling captagon, an illegal amphetamine, creating a new narcostate on the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Italian law enforcement officers seized 14 tons of captagon, about 84 million pills, at the port of Salerno last year.

item.title: Fatalities Reported After Military Truck Rams Protesters in Myanmar
item.description: Witnesses said soldiers also fired into the crowd and kicked wounded demonstrators, the latest in a series of confrontations in which the military’s behavior has infuriated citizens.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Soldiers detaining a protester after a crackdown on a demonstration in Yangon, Myanmar, on Sunday.

item.title: Refugees Who Left Lesbos With Pope in 2016 Settle Into Rome Life
item.description: Three Syrian families who traveled on the papal plane after the pope’s last visit to the Greek island have made new lives for themselves in Italy’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Wafaa Eid, center, and her husband, Osama Kawkji, center right, and their children were among the 12 Syrians who flew with Pope Francis to Rome from Greece in 2016.

item.title: Palestinian Who Stabbed Israeli in Jerusalem Is Killed by Police
item.description: The incident, captured in videos, was at least the fifth such knife attack in Jerusalem since September.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: An Israeli police officer standing guard near the Damascus Gate in Jerusalem’s Old City on Saturday.

item.title: Britain Counts Around 160 Omicron Cases and Tightens Restrictions
item.description: An additional testing requirement for travelers is being imposed, as well as a ban on visitors from Nigeria, where the variant was detected this week.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A makeshift vaccination center in west London on Saturday. With a new coronavirus variant circulating, Britain is implementing additional containment measures.

item.title: Angela Merkel Makes Final Plea for Germans to Get Vaccinated
item.description: ‘Every shot helps,’ the chancellor said, days before she leaves office.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel at her official military send-off in Berlin on Thursday. She is leaving office at a time when the pandemic is flaring up in Germany.

item.title: More Than 40,000 March in Vienna Against Coronavirus Restrictions
item.description: Protesters gathered for a second weekend of mass demonstrations against the country’s tough lockdown and a coming vaccine mandate.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:credit: Florian Wieser/Agence France-Presse, via Apa/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers clashing with protesters during a demonstration against Covid restrictions in Vienna on Saturday.

item.title: Spy Tool Was Deployed in State-Sponsored Hack of Ugandans
item.description: Two journalists and one politician said they received alerts warning them of “state-sponsored” attacks on their iPhones. At least one of those attacks was linked to the powerful Israeli cyberespionage tool, Pegasus.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: An office of the Israeli NSO group in November. The company, which developed the hacking software known as Pegasus, said it was unaware it had been used in Africa.

item.title: Man Who Had Omicron Says Friends Also Got Sick After NYC Anime Convention
item.description: Another case is reported in Connecticut that may be tied to the convention.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Joseph Goldstein, Roni Caryn Rabin, Patrick McGeehan and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
item.category: Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:description: Costumed people at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City on Nov. 20 for a three-day anime convention. It had begun the day before.

item.title: Switzerland Backtracks on Mandatory Quarantines for Some Foreign Visitors
item.description: Reservations for the Christmas vacation season had plummeted over the Covid restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Alain Berset, the Swiss health minister, in Bern on Friday. Switzerland is dropping a quarantine requirement for some visitors after many holiday reservations were canceled.

item.title: At Least 13 Dead as Indonesia's Mount Semeru Erupts
item.description: Dozens more suffered burns as lava flowed from the eruption of Mount Semeru, on the island of Java.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Indonesian National Board for Disaster Management, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
